Parameters Effects on fibers Effects on FZIBs Ref. Solution parameters Solution Concentration Increase in fiber diameter with increase of concentration. In terms of electrochemical performance, fine diameter fibers have a larger specific surface area, which provides more active sites during electrochemical processes. On the contrary, electrospun nanofiber for FZIBs generally requires high mechanical strength to mitigate the damage caused to the cell when bending or folding. Therefore, the solution concentration and surface tension can be appropriately increased in terms of electrospinning solution parameters to increase the fiber diameter and thus enhance the mechanical properties of the fibers. [47] Viscosity Low-beads generation, high-increase in fiber [48] Conductivity Decrease in fiber diameter with increase in conductivity [49] Surface tension No conclusive link with fiber morphology high surface tension results in instability of jets. [50] Processing variables Voltage In general, the fiber diameter will decrease when the voltage increases. At low voltage, beads will occur in the fibers. Similarly, it is possible to appropriately increase the voltage and flow rate in terms of operating parameters to produce fibers that meets the mechanical strength of FZIBs. Moreover, fibers with different structures, such as dendritic and ribbon fibers, can be prepared by adjusting the parameters to promote better deposition of Zn. [52] Tip-to-collector distance Within a certain range, finer fibers are formed with increasing distance [53] Feed rate Decrease in fiber diameter with decrease in flow rate, generation of beads with too high flow rate. [54] Spinneret Single nozzle easily assembled and widely used, coaxial facilitates the generation of nanofibers with core-shell or hollow structures. The porous and/or hollow structure not only provides a convenient pathway for the effective transport and diffusion of Zn2+, but also mitigates the structural strain and buffer volume change of the electrode material during repeated charging and discharging with excellent cycling stability. [58] Environmental conditions Temperature An increase in temperature reduces the surface tension and viscosity of the precursor solution, favouring fiber formation For better generation of continuous nanofiber, the temperature can be increased and humidity can be lowered appropriately. Graphical abstract The nanofiber prepared by electrospinning technique provides an effective way for the development of flexible zinc-ion battery components (anode, cathode, separator, and electrolyte) and all-in-one batteries. Flexible wearable batteries are widely used in smartwatches, foldable phones, and fitness trackers due to their thinness and small size. Zinc-based batteries have the advantages of low cost, high safety, and eco-friendliness, which are considered to be the best alternative to flexible lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). Therefore, wearable flexible zinc-ion batteries (FZIBs) have attracted considerable interest as a promising energy storage device. Electrospun nanofibers (ESNFs) have great potential for application in wearable FZIBs due to their low density, high porosity, large specific surface area, and flexibility. Moreover, electrospinning technology can achieve the versatility of nanofibers through structural design and incorporation of other multifunctional materials. This paper reviews a wide range of applications of electrospinning in FZIBs, mainly in terms of cathode, anode, separator, polymer electrolyte, and all-in-one flexible batteries. Firstly, the electrospinning device, principles, and influencing parameters are briefly described, showing its positive impact on FZIBs. Subsequently, the energy storage principles and electrode configurations of FZIBs are described, and some of the common problems of the batteries are illustrated, including zinc anode dendrite growth, corrosion, cathode structure collapse, and poor electrical conductivity. This is followed by a comprehensive overview of research progress on the individual components of FZIBs (cathode, anode, separator, and polymer electrolyte) from the perspective of electrostatically spun fiber materials and an in-depth study of all-in-one flexible batteries. Finally, the challenges and future development of FZIBs are individually concluded and look forward. We hope that this work will provide new ideas and avenues for the development of advanced energy technologies and smart wearable systems. Keywords Flexible zinc-ion batteries Flexible electrode materials Electrospinning Nanofibers 1 Introduction In recent years, flexible and wearable electronics, presenting prominent technological trends for future lifestyles, have attracted widespread interest in artificial skin, rollable displays, smart clothing, smart glasses, smart textiles, and implantable medical devices (Fig. 1 ). As the demand for smart electronics continues to increase, it stimulates the relentless pursuit of advanced flexible rechargeable power sources with high energy density and reliable electrochemical performance [1,2]. Undoubtedly, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), with their advantages of high energy density, high output voltage, and low self-discharge, dominate various electronic devices and are the main energy source for today's flexible electronic products [3]. However, the scarcity and uneven distribution of lithium resources, potential leakage of organic electrolytes, and corrosion risks have greatly limited the further application of LIBs. Therefore, it is imperative to explore a new generation of rechargeable flexible batteries that are highly safe, environmentally friendly, and low-cost [4,5]. Currently, zinc-based batteries (ZIBs) are considered a more viable alternative to traditional LIBs [6]. Zinc has many attractive advantages as an anode material compared to other metal cations [7] (Table 1 ). On the one hand, zinc itself is an abundant and low-cost metal, which makes ZIBs relatively inexpensive to manufacture and thus significantly improves the cost-effectiveness of the battery. On the other hand, ZIBs typically use a water-based electrolyte, which is less prone to problems such as thermal runaway, fire, and electrolyte leakage than batteries using organic electrolytes, making them safer for use in flexible devices that are subject to repeated bending, twisting, and other mechanical deformations. In addition to the excellent electrochemical performance of zinc, including low electrochemical potential (−0.762 V, compared to standard hydrogen electrodes) and high theoretical capacity (820 mA h g−1 or 5855 mA h cm−3), the insensitivity of zinc to the environment makes zinc-based batteries easier to manufacture and package than LIBs [8,9]. Therefore, ZIBs have a promising application in flexible wearable energy storage devices [10]. In 2012, Kang et al. proposed for the first time the concept of a low-cost and safe “zinc ion battery” based on the reversible Zn2+ insertion/extraction mechanism of MnO2 [11,12]. It has subsequently attracted the attention of a wide range of researchers and scholars, and has shown great potential in flexible wearable devices, consumer electronics and static energy storage, providing new ideas for the development of safe rechargeable flexible batteries [13]. Much of the current research on flexible zinc-ion batteries (FZIBs) is still confined to laboratory environments, and the tests performed on it are not the same as those performed on commercial equipment. Studies have shown that there have been many practical examples of the application of FZIBs. For example, Kaltenbrunner [14] and colleagues constructed wearable FZIBs as a power source for skin-on-skin electronics, and the integrated device worked normally under deformation conditions when the joints were moved. Similarly, Wang's team [15] constructed a wearable electronic skin patch, a system that enables convenient and effective detection of electrochemical signals. Meanwhile, Li et al. [16] also applied FZIBs to smart insoles; when people walk on the insoles, there is no power outage or short-circuit problem when running, and at the same time, the movement can be tracked and sent to mobile phones via Bluetooth. They are bridging the gap between laboratory research and real-world applications by conducting more extensive real-world evaluations of battery performance. The design and fabrication of safe rechargeable flexible batteries relies on the realisation of flexible components, such as cathodes, anodes, and separators, which should meet the characteristics of low cost, light weight, and bendability in order to better apply FZIBs in realistic scenarios [17,18]. Due to the advantages of high electrical conductivity, porousness, structural controllability, and significant nano-micron effect, nanofibrous materials show great application promise in improving the electrochemical performance of ZIBs, and are also ideal candidates for flexible battery devices [19–21]. Currently, electrospinning is one of the simplest and most versatile methods to obtain continuous nanofibrous materials with large specific surface area, many active sites, and flexibility in a continuous manner, and is highly promising for industrialisation. At the same time, there is a wide range of raw materials available for electrospinning, and polymers that can be melted or dissolved in water/organic solvents, such as polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF), polyacrylonitrile (PAN), and polypropylene (PP) can be realized by electrospinning. Even insoluble and immiscible polymers, such as polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), can be prepared by the emulsion spinning method with the aid of a spinning agent. In addition, due to its strong structural tunability, it is possible to prepare nanofibers with different structures (porous, hollow, etc.) by changing the electrospinning parameters, and it is easy to carry out doping and composite modification treatments based on this, so that the nanoeffects can be presented in the performance, which is particularly suitable for all configurations (cathode, anode, separator, etc.) of the ZIBs [22]. More importantly, the nanomaterials prepared by electrospinning are usually interconnected to form a three-dimensional (3D) network, which can greatly improve the structural stability and facilitate the transfer of Zn2+, thus improving the electrochemical performance [23]. Therefore, there is a great potential for wearable FZIBs through ESNFs, and the research progress of ESNFs in FZIBs is shown in Fig. 2 [24–32]. Currently, there are a lot of research about FZIBs and the application of electrospinning in ZIBs, and there also exist some reviews about them [33,34]. However, the review specifically focus on electrospinning in FZIBs has not been reported. Here, in order to be able to help others to systematically understand the research progress of electrospun filaments in FZIBs, we summarize how electrospun filaments have been used in recent years to implement wearable FZIBs. Firstly, after describing the fundamentals of electrospinning, parameter design and the effect of the external environment on the nanofibers, the effect of electrode configuration on the FZIBs is also discussed. Secondly, the technical challenges faced while realising FZIBs are illustrated, including electrode dissolution and structural collapse on the cathode side, as well as the presence of zinc dendrites, hydrogen evolution and corrosion on the anode side. The next section describes the application of ESNFs in FZIBs, we focusing on the improvement of electrode flexibility while addressing the aforementioned defects to improve the electrochemical performance of the cells. Finally, the current challenges facing FZIBs are present, and a brief summary and outlook on the application of ESNFs in FZIBs are provided. It is hoped that the systematic description in this paper will familiarise the reader with the basics of electrospinning and FZIBs as well as the advances in electrospinning technology in FZIBs, and inspire the reader to explore extensively for more novel and effective strategies. 2 Electrospinning technology In 1934, the electrospinning technique was used for the first time to produce polymer nanofibers by dissolving polymer precursors in a solvent. In addition to the original polymers, electrospinning materials now include metals, ceramics, semiconductors and proteins and their combinations [35]. Due to their large specific surface area, high porosity, unique nanostructures and composite properties, ESNFs have great potential for applications in energy storage [36], drug release [37], biosensing [38] and filtration [39,40]. Electrospinning devices are very simple and have been industrialised in many fields in recent years, and their production scale has been continuously expanded [41]. As shown in Fig. 3 , the electrospinning device mainly consists of a high-voltage power supply, a syringe fitted with a metal blunt-tipped needle and a collector [42]. In a typical electrospinning process, the polymer solution is loaded into a syringe and passed through a syringe pump into a spinneret, where it forms droplets acted upon by surface tension. When high voltage is applied between the spinneret and the collector, the electrostatic repulsion on the surface of the droplet drives it to elongate and form a conical structure called a Taylor cone [43]. When the applied voltage is increased to a critical value, the surface repulsive force will overcome the surface tension, resulting in the ejection of a liquid jet from the tip of the spinneret. As the surface is filled with an electrical-like charge, the liquid jet is elongated in the process by the electrostatic repulsion of the needle towards the collector, resulting in a reduction of the liquid jet diameter to hundreds or tens of nanometers [44]. In a typical process, the solvent in the liquid jet is evaporated and the cured polymer fibers form a soft, randomly oriented nonwoven mat [45,46]. A number of factors influence the diameter and morphology of electrostatically spun fibers (Table 2 ). (1) Solution parameters such as precursor type, conductivity and concentration or viscosity [47–50]: precursors influence the structure of the final fibers, such as diameter and length [51]. (2) Operational parameters [52–54] such as voltage [55], feed rate [56], distance between spinneret and collector [57], type of needle and collector [58]: optimization of these parameters is a prerequisite for controlling the generation of nanofibers, which allows for the preparation of complex nanostructures with controllable hierarchical features such as non-woven aligned or patterned fibers, nanoribbons, nanorods, random 3D structures, submicron springs, and diameter-controlled of curled fibers [59]. (3) Environmental parameters [60,61] such as room temperature and humidity: humidity affects the rate of evaporation of solvents and thus the rate of solidification of the jet. Temperature is another factor that affects fibers. An increase in temperature reduces the surface tension and viscosity of the precursor solution, which facilitates fiber formation. However, high temperatures cause the solvent to evaporate rapidly, limiting the extension of the jet. (4) Post-treatment process: in addition to the structural modulation achieved by changing the process parameters, the structural and compositional characteristics of ESNFs can be further adjusted by post-treatments such as heat treatment and activation [62]. In particular, certain electrospun materials can be transformed into carbon, metal oxides and their hybridisation products after high-temperature treatment under special atmospheres such as N2, Ar, H2, and O2. During this process, a porous structure is usually formed due to the removal of templates and the formation of gases, thus cushioning the component against the strain generated during bending, and the increase in porosity reduces the bulk modulus and shear modulus of the material, thus increasing its flexibility and being more favourable for FZIBs. More importantly, these pores can significantly increase the surface area of the electrode, providing more active sites and helping to increase the contact area between the electrode and the electrolyte. This is important for improving the charge transfer rate and insertion/extraction reaction efficiency of the electrode [63] The summarised electrospinning parameters and their effects on fibers and FZIBs are shown in Table 2. In summary, electrospinning, on the one hand, as one of the effective technologies capable of efficiently and continuously producing nanofibrous membranes, offers the possibility of preparing flexible membrane materials, and on the other hand, it makes it possible to fabricate nanomaterials with different advanced structures by means of multi-class structural modulation and multiple material configurations, which improves the electrochemical properties of ZIBs and is conducive to the realisation of flexible and high-performance ZIBs. 3 Flexible zinc-ion batteries 3.1 Principle of zinc-ion batteries FZIBs are composed of a flexible current collector, cathode and anode materials, a separator and an electrolyte in a neutral or weak acid system [64]. The structure and principle of FZIBs are basically the same as that of ZIBs as shown in Fig. 4 . For the charge/discharge mechanism of ZIBs, two processes are known, 1e− and 2e−, which are based on the Zn2+ insertion and extraction reactions occurring at the anode, where Zn2+ is electro-stripped/electro-plated accordingly near the anode surface. During charging the metal cations are detached from the cathode due to loss of electrons and pass through the electrolyte across the battery separator, gaining electrons on the other side to be embedded in the negative electrode material. Similarly during discharge the zinc anode is dissolved and releases Zn2+ ions through oxidation. These Zn2+ are detached from the cathode and inserted through the electrolyte into the cathode material, which typically has a layered or tunneled structure that facilitates the transport of these ions [65]. The Zn2+/H+ co-insertion phenomenon occurs when the cathode material is MnO2, and this process can be described by Eqs. (2) and (3) [66]. Anode: (1) Zn ↔ Zn2+ + 2e− Cathode: (2) Zn2+ + 2e− + 2MnO₂ ↔ ZnMn2O4 (3) MnO2 + H+ + e− ↔ MnOOH 3.2 Problems with flexible zinc-ion batteries While realising the flexibility of ZIBs, similar to normal ZIBs, there are still problems such as dendrites, hydrogen evolution and corrosion (as described below), and these effects are especially exacerbated when FZIBs are bent and folded at different angles. Therefore, we should pay more attention to solving these problems when realising FZIBs. In positive electrodes, the main problems include dissolution of active substances, poor structural stability, low energy density, capacity decay, and low variety of host selection [67,68]. (1) Dissolution of active substances, structural collapse: the chemical reaction of the cathode material is mainly determined by the salt and pH of the aqueous electrolyte. Alkaline electrolytes are more corrosive, and compared with them; acidic electrolytes can react better with anode. However, this will reduce the electrochemical performance and cycle stability of the cathode material, exacerbate the dissolution of the active substance, and finally lead to the collapse of the structure of the cathode material and the decline of the battery service life [69]. (2) Slow reaction kinetics, capacity decay: cathode materials depend more on charge transfer in terms of electrochemical capacity storage. When the rate of charge transfer decreases it leads to excessive electrochemical polarisation, which seriously affects the capacity density and multiplication capability of the battery [70]. (3) Few types of host selection: in ZIBs, Zn2+ as a charge carrier is characterized by high charge and heavy atomic mass. Therefore, there are fewer types of host materials suitable for Zn2+ storage [71]. In addition to this, the reaction window of conventional electrolytes is narrow, leading to a small selection of host materials. Therefore, the development of host materials with high zinc storage activity is one of the key research directions to advance the practical application of flexible zinc ion storage chemistry [72]. In zinc anodes, dendrites, hydrogen evolution and corrosion tend to occur. (1) Dendrites: The plating/stripping of zinc is often uneven, resulting in a rough surface appearance and the growth of zinc dendrites, which is also known as the “tip effect” [73,74]. As shown in the cathode of Fig. 4, Zn2+ initially tends to be deposited in the region of higher Zn concentration, and due to its larger surface energy, subsequent Zn nucleation grows spontaneously in the existing protrusions The presence of a partially high electric field and the concentration of Zn2+ promotes the nucleation and growth of the Zn metal at localised points, and gradually evolves into Zn dendrites [75]. (2) Hydrogen evolution: hydrogen evolution from chemical and electrochemical reactions is an unavoidable side reaction in ZIBs. Hydrogen evolution requires the consumption of a certain amount of charge during the charging process, which may increase the local pH and affect the Zn2+ deposition behaviour. More importantly, the generation of hydrogen bubbles leads to more defects and increases the internal pressure of the sealed cell, resulting in cell swelling. Zinc is an amphoteric metal that reacts chemically with small amounts of H+ in acids and large amounts of OH− in bases to produce hydrogen released by electrochemical reactions during hydrogen charging as shown in Eqs. (1) and (3). (3) Corrosion: there are two types of corrosion in zinc-based batteries, self-corrosion and electrochemical corrosion. Self-corrosion occurs mainly in alkaline environments and refers to the irreversible electrochemical corrosion depletion of the zinc anode during charging and discharging, including the detachment of zinc from the electrodes into the electrolyte and the formation of by-products such as Zn4SO4(OH)6·xH2O [76]. The process can be written as follows. (4) Zn − 2e− ↔ Zn2+ (5) 4Zn2+ + 6OH− + SO42− + xH₂O ↔ Zn4SO4(OH)6·xH2O In separators and electrolytes, they are in direct contact with the electrodes, which gives them a unique advantage in coordinating the internal components of the cell. However, conventional separators are characterized by low mechanical strength and varying pore sizes, which can seriously affect the mechanical properties and ion transport rates of FZIBs, and are not conducive to the development of flexible all-in-one batteries [77]. The electrolyte can provide the most basic working environment for other components in the battery, thus ensuring high compatibility and reversible cycling of each component. Moreover, some of the problems mentioned above for cathode and anode can be mitigated by different electrolyte strategies, thus improving the overall electrochemical performance and cycling stability of the battery. Currently, hydrogel electrolytes are well developed in flexible batteries, providing a more effective direction for developing flexible wearable ZIBs [78]. As all these problems mentioned above may hinder the development process of ZIBs and have attracted research from a wide range of scholars. Therefore, these issues also need to be taken into account when designing the structure of FZIBs. 4 Progress of electrospinning materials in flexible zinc-ion batteries As a unique and versatile method, electrospinning, in addition to the aforementioned advantages of simple equipment, wide range of raw material sources, and tunable structure, it exhibits some features in ZIBs that are not found in other methods. (1) ESNFs have a large charge transfer reaction surface and abundant electrolyte ion entry sites, which significantly reduces the reaction impedance. (2) The nanofibers provide a continuous fast channel for electron transfer, thus minimising the interparticle resistance encountered in other material structures. The diffusion length of ions in the fibers is also greatly reduced, which is considered key to high power batteries design [79,80]. (3) The technique allows the efficient preparation of one-dimensional (1D) nanofibers, two-dimensional (2D) non-woven membranes and 3D frameworks with fiber diameters down to the micro-nanometer scale. Fibrous membranes with higher porosity are also easier to obtain through random stacking of ESNFs. The porous structure facilitates the migration of ions throughout the network, thus improving the conductivity of the cell [81]. (4) Electrospun polymer fibers offer the possibility of preparing flexible inorganic fibers, such as a wide range of metal oxides, carbon-based fiber networks with a rich mesoporous structure. These ESNFs have a large surface area-to-volume ratio and good flexibility to accommodate a variety of configurations [64]. It is because of these advantages that ESNFs are widely used in FZIBs as materials for electrodes, electrolytes and separators [55,82]. 4.1 Electrospinning cathodes The cathode is an important component in FZIBs and plays a decisive role in their electrochemical performance [76]. Currently, research on cathode materials focuses on the following types of materials [83]: manganese-based oxides (MnOs) [84], vanadium-based oxides (VBOs) [85], polyanionic compounds [86], prussian blue analogue [87,88], conductive polymers [89], transition metal dichalcogenides [90]. The cathode of FZIBs generally suffers from a number of problems that need to be further investigated and solved, as described in 3.2 stated mainly including cathodic dissolution, structural collapse and volume expansion. In addition, the poor conductivity of the anode material also limits the electrochemical capacity of FZIBs. Therefore, these problems have adverse effects on the construction of high-performance and high-capacity FZIBs. In order to solve the problems existing in the positive electrode, electrospinning provides a simple, convenient and green unique technology to prepare FZIBs electrodes: on the one hand, electrospinning technology can construct electrode materials with diverse structures through the components of precursors, electrospinning parameters, environmental control and subsequent treatment, so that they have a large specific surface area, a large number of active sites, and the positive electrode is highly reversible in the insertion/extraction process of Zn2+ Characteristics. More Zn2+ should be embedded in each molecular unit at the same time the battery voltage does not change much with the state of charging and discharging. On the other hand, in order to adapt to the requirements of large-scale energy storage, electrode materials with excellent electrochemical properties can be obtained by blending with metal oxides, metal-organic skeletons (MOFs), and carbon nanomaterials, which prevents structural collapse and improves the charge/discharge rate of the FZIBs, with stable performance and high ion transport rate. The content of this part is based on the FZIBs cathode materials constructed by electrospinning: we focus on MnOs and VnOs, and systematically introduce some material design strategies to solve the problems of cathodes and enhance the performance of FZIBs cathodes by electrospinning technology. 4.1.1 Manganese-based oxides Manganese-based materials have become one of the most widely researched active materials for ZIBs due to their environmental friendliness, low cost and abundant resources, especially manganese oxides [91,92] and their composites [93–95]. In recent years, MnOs including MnO2 [96], Mn2O3 [97], Mn3O4 [91], and ZnMn2O4 [98] with different crystal structures are one of the most promising positive electrodes for ZIBs, and furthermore, manganese-based materials (including Mn x O y and its composites) are inexpensive, low-toxicity, and sustainable resources [99]. However, typical α-MnO2 [100] suffers from severe capacity degradation due to uncontrollable MnO2/Mn2+ deposition/dissolution [101] interfacial reactions during repeated charge/discharge cycles [102]. On the one hand, the indistinguishable solvation structures of hydrated Zn2+ and Mn2+, without obvious kinetic properties, result in the competitive reaction and co-deposition of a formed product, such as ZnMn2O4, with low electrochemical activity. On the other hand, agglomeration caused by low interface potential will cause uneven and irreversible deposition at the MnO2 interface, which causes interfacial kinetics deterioration during the cycle [103]. Composite with carbon-related materials (carbon cloth, graphene, carbon nanofibers and reduced graphene oxide, etc.) via electrospinning technology as a conductive substrate for cathode materials is an effective strategy to inhibit irreversible structural evolution and mitigate manganese dissolution. What's more, the electrochemical performance of MnOs can be greatly improved, while the substrate has better flexibility, which provides the possibility of wearable energy [104]. By compositing MnO2 with highly conductive graphene, the carbon material can provide more conductive pathways, which greatly improves the interfacial electron transfer kinetics and effectively enhances the structural stability and conductivity [105]. It was shown that Guo et al. [106] prepared porous carbon fiber (PCF)-loaded MnO2 anodes (PCF@MnO2) by electrospinning technique using poly(methyl methacrylate)-poly(acrylonitrile) block copolymers (PMMA-b-PAN) as raw materials, in which nanometer-thick MnO2 was uniformly deposited on the electrospun block copolymers derived from PCFs with abundant uniform mesopores (Fig. 5 a and b). PCF has high electrical conductivity, which enables the MnO2 carrier to achieve a fast electrochemical reaction while the porous nonwoven fiber facilitates rapid ion transport, enabling PCF@MnO2 to achieve excellent high rate performance at high loadings (Fig. 5c). In addition to this, carbon nanofibers (CNFs) with unique hollow 1D nanostructure have been widely used as conductive materials for MnOs. Due to their high aspect ratio and excellent conductivity, CNFs exhibit better electrochemical kinetics than conventional carbon substrates [107]. For example, Yang et al. [31] prepared highly flexible nitrogen-doped carbon films (Fig. 5d) by electrospinning technique and calcination method using PAN, PVP, 2-methylimidazole, and zinc acetate as raw materials, in which the evaporation of Zn at high carbonation temperature led to the porous structure of CNFs (Fig. 5e). Layered K+ intercalated δ-MnO2 (KMO) was loaded onto the surface of the CNFs by the KMnO4 hydrothermal method, and the obtained KMO/CNFs had a large surface area, which enlarged the contact area between KMO and the electrolyte, and facilitated the ion transfer (Fig. 5f). More importantly, KMO/CNFs have excellent flexibility and their membranes can be folded like a piece of paper, which provides a feasible method for constructing flexible carbon film anodes with high-performance FZIBs. Carbon-based materials have many excellent properties, but their flexibility is not good. Therefore, in order to improve the electrode flexibility, polymer electrospun carbon nanofibers can be used as cathode collector or active substance carrier, which can improve the electrical conductivity, flexibility and active substance utilisation of cathode materials. Hiralal et al. [24] prepared flexible carbon nanofiber membranes by electrospinning technique using methanol solution of phenolic resin and poly(vinyl butyral) (PVB) as a precursor, which can be used as a cathode current collector and active substance carrier, and loaded with manganese oxide nanoparticles to enhance the conductivity of the electrodes. The finally fabricated flexible solid-state battery (Fig. 6 a) can work even under mechanical stress, as can be seen from the initial discharge curves (Fig. 6b), relatively small changes in the discharge characteristics were observed during strain measurements, suggesting that the mechanical properties of the layers are good. The use of carbon-based materials as substrates is a fundamental approach to optimise the conductivity of manganese-based compounds, but the link between carbon fibers and active substances is not yet strong. Therefore, to solve this problem, the active substance can be embedded in CNFs to inhibit the dissolution of manganese-based materials, increase the active sites and provide fast channels for ion transfer. It was shown that Ding et al. [108] prepared nanofiber primary membranes by electrostatic electrospinning using Mn-MOFs and PAN as raw materials (Fig. 6c and d).The decomposition of Mn-MOFs and PAN was converted into beaded manganese oxides coated with CNFs (Fig. 6e). This strategy can effectively improve the ion diffusion kinetics and maintain the stability of the electrode structure. These advantages of the MnO x -CNFs are evident in the electrochemical performance indices, with very long cycling durability (i.e., capacity retention of 90.6% after 2000 cycles and 71% after 5000 cycles) and excellent multiplication capability (Fig. 6f). With improved performance, in order to fabricate self-supported positive electrodes to enable future wearable FZIBs, Chen et al. [30] designed oxygen-rich defective MnO1− x with carbon nanofiber (MnO1− x @CNF) integrated membranes by electrospinning manganese acetate and annealing at 260 and 800 °C (Fig. 6g). The introduction of oxygen vacancies can effectively promote H+ diffusion. In addition, CNFs can provide a flexible and lightweight electron transfer network to ensure fast electrode reaction kinetics. As a result, the prepared MnO1− x @CNF anode has high specific capacity and excellent capacity retention (Fig. 6i). Due to the excellent mechanical properties of the nanofibers, the film could be bent to different degrees and still recovered to its original appearance without visible creases, and the cycling stability was not greatly affected (Fig. 6h). More notably, the prepared MnO1− x @CNF film can be directly used as the cathode of ZIBs. It does not need to be mixed with a conductive agent and binder to form a paste and then coated on the current collector. The high flexibility and light weight of the MnO1− x @CNF film contribute to the future high-performance cathode for wearable FZIBs. However, such a strategy of embedding active materials would somehow be detrimental to the ion transport efficiency and the utilisation of active materials. Therefore, the precise adjustment of electrospinning parameters, along with the use of multicomponent materials for electrospinning precursor formulation and the use of post-treatment process followed by heteroatom doping, carbon coating and morphological structure modulation are the keys to obtain anode with excellent electrochemical performance. Chen et al. [109] synthesized three-dimensional porous Mn2O3 nanofibers by electrospinning-annealing process using Mn(Ac)2·4H2O and PVP as raw materials (Fig. 7 a–c). The composition and structure could be easily adjusted by adjusting the precursor solution and process parameters. In addition, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) were added to enhance the electrical conductivity. The Mn2O3 cathode formed at an annealing temperature of 500 °C exhibited excellent multiplicity performance and outstanding cycling performance (Fig. 7d and e), which was superior to many reported Mn2O3 cathode materials. Using carbon coating this method can effectively slow down or inhibit cathode dissolution and structural collapse, and improve the electrical conductivity and ion migration rate of cathode materials. Tang et al. [110] successfully synthesized nitrogen-doped carbon-coated manganese oxide (MnO@N-C) composite fibers using an electrospinning in-situ strategy (Fig. 7f and g), which was subsequently improved by the annealing process to effectively solve the aforementioned problems. Its reversible capacity of 176.3 mA h g−1 was still provided after 200 cycles at 0.5 A g−1 (Fig. 7h and i). Because the prepared product has a special structure with a large number of fibers that are randomly oriented to form an interwoven three-dimensional network, it provides an important reference for the construction of MnOs in FZIBs. In addition to this, it can be combined with different structures of electrospinning spinnerets to produce nanofibers with special structures (hollow, porous). Long et al. [111] synthesized core-shell Mn3O4@C hybrid fibers using coaxial electrospinning technique by embedding Mn3O4 nanoparticles in hollow carbon fibers (Mn3O4@HCFs) (Fig. 7j and k). As a cathode for ZIBs, it has a capacity of 215.8 mA h g−1 at 0.3 A g−1. As the core-shell structure of Mn3O4@HCFs has a large amount of void space, it can significantly increase the surface area of the electrodes and provide more active sites, which improve the electron conductivity within the fibers (Fig. 7l). In addition, the hollow carbon skeleton reduces electrode dissolution while mitigating the expansion of Mn3O4 volume during the discharge process. The reported cathode electrospun fibers and their electrochemical properties are shown in Table 3 . 4.1.2 Vanadium-based oxides Vanadium-based oxides (V x O y ) are commonly used as cathode materials for ZIBs due to the different oxidation states (V x +, x = 2,3,4,5) and redox properties of vanadium [68]. The basic V-O coordination polyhedra can be assembled into different vanadium oxide framewors (e.g., tetrahedra to square pyramids and triangular bipyramids to twisted and ortho-octahedra). These complex polyhedra and successive variations of V oxidation can actually be adjusted to accommodate better insertion of Zn2+ into the interlayer spacing/channels, whereas the conventional mechanism of V-based is to insert/extract Zn2+ in selected host materials. In other words, during charging, vanadium ions are transformed from a lower oxidation state (e.g., V2+) to a higher oxidation state (e.g., V3+) while absorbing charge, and during discharging, the vanadium ions are reduced from a higher oxidation state back to a lower oxidation state, releasing the stored charge while releasing energy, and this redox reaction can be repeated, resulting in “ well ” electrochemical performance [112]. However, due to the strong polarity of the water molecules and anions, the V-based cathode exhibits vanadium solubilisation when cycling in ZIBs, especially in weakly acidic aqueous solutions. The V-based cathode cycling at low current densities reflects capacity decay due to the co-insertion of coordinated water molecules and Zn2+, which form hydrogen bonds with lattice O2−, weakening the strength of the V–O bond, and therefore the dissolution of the active material into the electrolyte as the redox reaction proceeds, leading to increased structural collapse [70,113]. In order to improve these situations, it has been shown that the formation of nanostructures can effectively alleviate these limitations [114]. In recent years, studies on V x O y nanostructures [115] have focused on nanowires [116,117], nanofibers [118], nanoribbons [119], and nanosheets [120]. Electrospinning method has the advantages of simplicity, economy and versatility. The V x O y nanofibers prepared using the electrospinning techniques have excellent ion diffusion pathways, high electrical conductivity and high flexibility, which can facilitate electron/ion transfer and improve the cycling capacity of the positive electrode. Importantly, it provides an effective help for realising wearable FZIBs. Pure V2O5 nanofibers have the disadvantage of insufficient flexibility, so in order to improve the electrode flexibility, composite vanadium-based nanofiber electrode materials prepared by hybrid electrospinning or loading methods can be used, which can improve the capacity and cyclic charge/discharge stability of vanadium-based materials. For example, Volkov et al. [121] used electrospinning to synthesise V2O5 nanofibers (Fig. 8 a) as cathode materials for rechargeable ZIBs. The 1D longitudinal electron transfer pathway can reduce the diffusion length of Zn2+ and thus increase the ion mobility efficiently. Using CNFs as the carrier, the high conductive 3D mesh structure was utilised to give the cathode material a high initial capacity and good capacity retention (Fig. 8b), and the electrode still maintained significant electrochemical activity after 500 cycles (Fig. 8c). In order to inhibit vanadium-based dissolution and structural collapse, Liu et al. [122] produced a self-supported anode with high specific capacity by filling CNFs with vanadium oxide nanoparticles via electrospinning technique (Fig. 8d). The fiber film has a unique nanostructure, which can be directly used as an anode while inhibiting the dissolution of vanadium, avoiding the need for additional additives. Moreover, the synthetic nanofiber film has excellent properties, such as high zinc storage capacity (319 mA h g−1 at 0.1 A g−1), fast discharge-charge characteristics, and outstanding cycling stability (215 mA h g−1 at 20 A g−1, 67.4% capacitance at 0.1 A g−1, and 63% capacity retention at 18,000 cycles) (Fig. 8e). However, while improving the electrochemical performance of the cathode, we also need to focus on the flexibility of the electrode. The electrospinning method is versatile as well as adaptable in the fabrication of composite V2O5 nanofibers [123]. Therefore, Xu et al. [124] prepared a flexible vanadium pentoxide carbon fiber cloth (V2O5-CFC) by dissolving V2O5 and PAN in dimethylformamide (DMF) using electrospinning and high-temperature calcination (Fig. 8f and g). n-doped CNFs constructed a three-dimensional network with a large specific surface area, which ensured a fast charge transfer and improved the conductivity of the material. As a cathode material for ZIBs, V2O5-CFC has a significantly improved specific capacity (up to 132 mA h g−1 at 1 A g−1) and a good cycling ability (up to 154 mA h g−1 after 1000 cycles at 0.5 A g−1) (Fig. 8h). What is more, V2O5-CFC shows good flexibility properties (Fig. 8i and j), demonstrating the flexibility performance test of the material at different bending degrees, which provides ideas for future applications in wearable FZIBs with high energy density. Gradient materials have attracted much attention because of their gradient composition distribution that makes them suitable for specific operating conditions. By adjusting the concentration distribution of precursors during electrospinning, nanofibers with continuous concentration gradients can be produced [125]. Hu et al. [126] proposed a composite method combining the dynamic concentration adjustment method with electrospinning technology to prepare continuous gradient composite films (GCF) containing VO nanoparticles. Compared with the homogeneous or degraded types, the conductivity of the composite membranes gradually increased with the gradient distribution of VO nanoparticles in the carbon fiber matrix, which was conducive to the rapid transfer of electrons, thus improving the reaction kinetics and electrochemical properties. Building microstructures is an effective strategy to inhibit the volume expansion of cathode materials and enhance the structural stability of cathode materials. The construction of porous, hollow and layered structures such as by electrospinning will help to improve the contact area between the electrode and the electrolyte, increase the charge transfer rate and the insertion/extraction reaction efficiency of the electrode, and thus improve the transport kinetics of the cathode material effectively [127]. Therefore, Chen et al. [128] prepared porous V2O5 nanofiber anodes with high Zn storage performance by electrospinning (Fig. 9 a). The initial discharge specific capacity of the obtained V2O5 nanofibers was 265 mA h g−1, and the constant-current charge-discharge curve at 20 mA g−1 between 0.5 and 1.5 V is shown in Fig. 9(b). In the first discharge, V2O5 was converted to zinc pyrovanadate (ZVO). ZVO has a lamellar structure consisting of octahedral layers of ZnO6 (Fig. 9c), and this open and stable architecture gives it a high reversible capacity (319 mA h g−1 at 20 mA g−1) and strong cycling stability (81% capacity retention after 500 cycles). Highly flexible stand-alone cathode materials are the key to realising FZIBs. To improve the electrode flexibility performance, Wang et al. [27] reported a novel core-shell hierarchical structured hybrid fiber coated with Zn2V2O7 and V2O5 nanoparticles (Fig. 9e) and used it as a flexible cathode for ZIBs. The hierarchical hybrid fibers consisting of a 1D central hollow shell and an internal carbon network were in-situ, and the formed metal oxide nanoparticles constructed bicontinuous conductive channels and highly porous networks (Fig. 9d). Meanwhile, the hierarchical structure enables fast electron transfer and efficient electrolyte penetration, both of which ensure the fast electrochemical kinetics of the electrode (Fig. 9g). This electrode can maintain good performance under high external deformation (Fig. 9f), especially excellent power density and good long-term cycling stability. This demonstrates the good energy storage capacity and fast charge/discharge capability of the ZIBs, which further promotes its application in wearable flexible electronics. Doping technique is one of the most effective solutions to improve its electrochemical properties. Due to the openness or flexibility of the V2O5 structure, by doping metal ions in the matrix, the layer spacing and rearrangement can be adjusted to effectively change its geometry, thus positively affecting its structure, conductivity and ion diffusion coefficient [129]. In order to improve the overall ion and electron transport properties of ZIBs, Geun Yoo et al. [130] fabricated doped V2O5 nanorods by electrospinning and thermal treatment (Fig. 10 a and b). Fe doping in the V2O5 matrix increased the number of electrically active sites and improved the movement of electrons, resulting in improved ion rate performance. The batteries composed of this cathode material achieved high specific capacities of 422 and 256 mA h g−1 at current densities of 0.5 and 2.0 A g−1, respectively, and maintained 85% long-term cycling stability after 160 cycles (Fig. 10c), and very stable ion diffusion capability even after cycling tests. The generation of different nanofiber structures by optimising the electrospinning parameters while doping can effectively mitigate vanadium dissolution and aggregation and ensure the stability of the electrodes. Song et al. [32] designed a series of V2O3 nanorods with different morphologies (solid, core-shell and hollow) and embedded with n-doped CNFs by using electrospinning and heat treatment techniques (Fig. 10f). Among these three structures, the hollow structure (V2O3-CNFs-H) of V2O3 nanorods can promote the penetration of electrolyte and alleviate the volume expansion. In addition, the abundant oxygen vacancies in V2O3 can provide enough active sites to reduce the electrostatic reaction between O and Zn2+ and facilitate the rapid diffusion of Zn2+. As a result, the V2O3/C-H//Zn cell provided excellent cycling stability (202 mA h g−1 after 5 A g−1 1000 cycles) and outstanding rate capacity (192 mA h g−1 at 10 A g−1) (Fig. 10g). Even when assembled into FZIBs, the samples still have excellent electrochemical properties, which provide a new idea for the design of flexible cathode materials for ZIBs. Defect engineering can optimise the electronic structure of the active material to modulate the electronic conductivity and kinetics of Zn2+ insertion/extraction [131]. Yoo [132] formed interfacially defective V2O5 nanosheets on an electrospun PAN pad by burning graphene. As the carbothermal reduction removed part of the oxygen in the V2O5 lattice, defects were formed on the surface of the V2O5 nanochips and the morphology was paper-like and disordered (Fig. 10d). This structure gives the framework a high specific capacity, rate capability, and long-term cycling stability with a high energy density of 437 W h kg−1 at a power density of 450 W kg−1 (Fig. 10e). In addition to the doping technique, the preparation of VO nanofiber electrode materials with physical and chemical defects by electrospinning also improves the electrochemical performance and structural stability of vanadium-based electrode active materials. Chen et al. [133] obtained vanadium oxide nanofibers (VCN) by electrospinning and heat treatment (Fig. 10h and i). The chemical defects present in vanadium oxides and carbon shells facilitated the insertion/extraction of Zn2+. Meanwhile, the abundant physical defects of VCN such as the layered porous structure would provide more storage sites for Zn ions to facilitate ion diffusion. Compared with V2O5, the Zn//VCN cell has a capacity retention of about 83% and a Coulombic efficiency close to 100% at 5 A g−1 after cycling for more than 1000 cycles (Fig. 10j). These excellent electrochemical performances and efficient transport can be attributed to the synergistic effect of the dual defects. The electrochemical properties of electrospun VBOs are summarised in Table 4 . 4.1.3 Other cathode materials In addition to manganese-based and vanadium-based materials as electrodes, electrospinning technology provides an effective way to develop other cathode materials. Coatings, conductive polymers, and MOFs have been used to explore composite cathode materials for high-efficiency, high-quality energy storage devices, and are a key step in promoting the development of FZIBs. Coatings are introduced into ZIBs cathode materials to improve electrode active site utilisation, electrode's ability to prevent rise and fall, and electrical conductivity. The nano-coating acts as a physical static barrier, isolating the electrode surface from the electrolyte, thereby inhibiting the dissolution and side reactions of the active substance without compromising the overall conductivity. Yang et al. [29] obtained PAN electrospun carbon fibers (N-CNFs) from VO(acac)2/PAN, PVP/DMF by electrospinning and heat treatment. As a substrate material, an ultra-thin alumina coating was developed by atomic layer deposition to prepare highly flexible VSe2 nanosheets@N-CNFs films, which were used as the cathode of flexible solid-state aqueous ZIBs. The obtained films maintained an excellent tensile strength of 230 MPa, a capacity retention of 86.2% and a Coulombic efficiency of 99.8% after 2500 cycles, further demonstrating the excellent structural stability and fast Zn2+ kinetics as a key step to facilitate the development of FZIBs. Using a similar approach, Xu et al. [134] developed a hybrid carbon coating (NVP/C/CNFs) interconnected with CNFs as a cathode for ZIBs using the electrospinning method (Fig. 11 b and c). The addition of CNFs resulted in a composite electrode material with a higher Zn2+ diffusion coefficient compared to NVP/C. The homogeneous carbon amorphous structure effectively mitigates vanadium dissolution during cycling, while the CNFs network further improves the electrical conductivity and structural stability of the cell as a whole (Fig. 11a and d). Conductive polymers are excellent cathode materials for zinc batteries due to their high conductivity, low cost, and ease of synthesis, and have good energy storage properties. Meanwhile, they have good flexibility compared with inorganic compounds, which is an important research direction for FZIBs, and have received wide attention in wearable electronics. Polyaniline (PANI) is one of the most common conductive polymers, and Kim et al. [26] used electrospinning, laser micromachining, and 3D printing to fabricate high-power ZIBs in different shapes (Fig. 11e). The PANI/CF cathode (Fig. 11f and g) has a high surface area and electrical conductivity, yielding a high rate (∼600 C) performance. Due to the excellent stability of Zn-PANI cells against oxygen and moisture, they exhibit excellent cycling stability in aqueous solutions of electrolytes. To highlight the flexibility of the design, the prepared rechargeable battery packs are stacked with electrodes to demonstrate wearable optoelectronic sensors by making the toroidal battery packs in the same shape as the electronic components. MOFs are a new class of functional materials made of metal ions coordinated with organic ligands. With the advantages of large specific surface area, tunable structure, abundant active sites and excellent flexibility, they are considered as promising cathode materials for FZIBs. Cui et al. [135] synthesised NiCo2S4@CF thin films through an innovative combination of PAN electrospinning and MOFs derivatisation strategies (Fig. 12 a and b). It is structurally flexible, lightweight and does not contain any polymer binder, while its composition gives it the advantages of high electrical conductivity, abundant electroactive sites, fast ion diffusion and high structural stability. When used as cathode, it showed a high capacity of 343.1 mA h g−1 at a current density of 3.8 A g−1, as well as superior rate performance and good cycling performance (Fig. 12d), and the FZIBs composed of this electrode have good flexibility and can still light up the LEDs when bent at different angles (Fig. 12c and e). The flexible and freestanding 3D framework can provide ZIBs with high structural integrity and ultra-long cycle life, while the layered structure can increase ion diffusivity and improve electrochemical performance. It was shown that vanadium nitride-embedded nitrogen-doped carbon nanofibers (VN/N-CNFs) composites with three-dimensional self-supporting skeleton and layered structure were prepared by Zhang et al. [136] using electrospinning method and heat treatment (Fig. 11f and g). The simultaneous introduction of vanadium-based metal skeletons (V-MOFs) uniformly distributed the VN nanoparticles in the nanofibers, which improved the mechanical flexibility and electrochemical properties of their structures (Fig. 12h) and contributed to the realisation of the FZIBs. In addition, the protective electrically conductive carbon matrix prepared from the functional V-MOFs and the electrically spun nanofibers could be provided with encapsulated shells by controlling the direct contact with the aqueous electrolyte, thus inhibiting the vanadium dissolution. Table 5 summarises some of the electrochemical properties of other cathode materials. In summary, both MnOs and VBOs have been extensively investigated in order to obtain cathode materials with high capacity, high cycling performance, low cost and good mechanical properties. Among them, in addition to ESNFs that can provide highly conductive carbonaceous frameworks and flexible 3D networks to improve the conductivity and flexibility of the electrodes, ionic embedding and oxygen vacancy generation of some cathode materials are also included to improve the electrochemical performance of FZIBs. So far, the lifetime and performance of cathodes have been greatly improved, but there are still challenges of manganese-based dissolution and poor stability of vanadium-based at low current densities, which seriously limit their practical applications. In order to solve the problems of cathode, many modification methods have been proposed, including guest substance pre-intercalation, nanostructure modulation, surface coating, introduction of defects, and inorganic-organic hybrid electrodes, which are more worthwhile to be investigated. However, a single strategy cannot comprehensively solve all the problems in the battery system, and concerted action is needed to promote electrochemical in situ transformations that contribute to the formation of beneficial structures. In addition, new, more stable cathode materials can be developed, such as molybdenum-based oxides, metal phosphides, or sulfur will be important to development of ZIBs for grid-scale energy storage. Besides, polyoxovanadates (POVs) exhibit unique properties, such as the ability to construct a variety of cluster structures through the multiple valence state of V and perform rich coordination chemistry under controlled experimental conditions. 4.2 Electrospinning anodes The most commonly used anode in FZIBs is Zn foil, and the Zn anode has a significant effect on the electrochemical performance of ZIBs with the following advantages: (1) Zn anode with excellent electrical conductivity accelerates electron transport [137] and promotes Zn deposition/dissolution. (2) Abundant Zn metal resources, simple processing and low cost. (3) Compared with aluminium, sodium and magnesium, zinc metal is stable in the presence of water and has better corrosion resistance, as well as good theoretical specific capacity [138] and volume capacity. However, the zinc metal plating/stripping process is inevitably affected by dendrites, corrosion and passivation as described in 3.2, leading to the continuous depletion of zinc anodes and accelerated rate of battery performance decline, greatly limiting the further practical application of zinc anodes [139]. Flexible anode with excellent electrochemical performance is the key to the development of flexible battery devices, and a lot of efforts have been made to solve the problems of anode zinc dendrite, corrosion and passivation [140–144]. Among the many solutions, the construction of functional substrates and functional interlayers with high specific surface area, excellent electrical conductivity, adjustable structure and good flexibility through electrospinning technology is an effective and direct strategy to protect the zinc anode and ensure the flexibility of the battery at the same time [145]. 4.2.1 Functional substrates The construction of a substrate helps to reduce the local current density and promote the uniform distribution of Zn2+, which is conducive to the uniform deposition of Zn and inhibits the growth of dendrites. CNFs have been widely used in electrochemical energy storage devices and have the following advantages over other materials. (1) Good electrical conductivity: CNFs have excellent electrical conductivity, which helps to improve the electrical conductivity of electrodes and promote electron transport. (2) High surface area: with high specific surface area, they provide more active sites, which is conducive to the charge transfer between electrodes and electrolyte. (3) Mechanical strength: CNFs usually have good mechanical strength, which enhances the structural stability of electrodes. In energy storage devices such as rechargeable batteries and supercapacitors, CNFs play a multifunctional role as active electrode materials, conductive additives, and substrates supporting active metals (oxides). Electrospinning provides a low-cost and scalable technique to fabricate CNFs and their hybrids with different nanostructures [146]. Therefore, using electrospinning technology to use the prepared CNFs membrane as a substrate is useful for improving the flexibility, service life, coulombic efficiency and cycling stability of ZIBs, and also offers the possibility of realising flexible wearable ZIBs [147]. Baek et al. [148] generated ZnCNF by electrospinning and heat treatment (Fig. 13 a) as a conductive substrate for the negative electrode of rechargeable zinc-metal batteries. When Zn-deposited CNFs were used, the electro-plating/stripping potential was reduced by 60.1%, and the symmetric cell exhibited a more stable ionic transport after 400 cycles at a current density of 0.1 mA cm−2 and a face capacity of 0.1 mA h cm−2. Moreover, the use of plasma-treated PAN electrospun CNFs as the substrate material resulted in more active sites and improved deposition and uniformity. In addition to the electrospun material alone as a substrate, the flexible 3D CNFs network with its high specific surface area and electrical conductivity is also an ideal vehicle for zinc deposition. The 3D structural design provides a larger surface area compared to conventional 2D structures, which allows more electrode material to come into contact with the electrolyte, thus increasing the active surface area of the electrodes; with better electronic and ionic conductivity properties, as they allow for shorter electronic and ionic transport paths. The reduced resistance helps to reduce the energy loss inside the battery and increase the energy conversion efficiency of the battery. It is therefore considered an effective method of protecting zinc anodes [63]. Therefore, Li et al. [149] prepared zinc anode CNF skeleton with 3D structure (Zn@CNF), the 3D structure and graphite surface can effectively inhibit the growth of dendrites using electrospinning technique. The 3D framework (Fig. 13b) can be used as a lightweight and sturdy carrier to enable the porous zinc electrode to have a long cycle life in a symmetric cell with a 10% discharge depth and 0.5 mA cm−2. The cycle life of Zn@CNF was up to 843 h, and the capacity of the full cell was 133.4 mA h g−1 at 0.1 A g−1. The capacity retention of the cell reached 92.1% after 260 cycles at 0.5 A g−1 (Fig. 13c). The introduction of Zn-friendly substances (n-doped, Cu, Zn, TiO2, Sn, Ag, etc.) with high adsorption capacity for Zn2+ into the 3D conductive substrate can enhance the interfacial interactions between the substrate and Zn2+, further modulate the nucleation and deposition of Zn2+, and improve the cycling life of the Zn anode [150]. In general, zinc-friendly materials have the following characteristics [151]: (1) the high adsorption of zinc by the zincophilic material leads to a low nucleation barrier for zinc; (2) the good surface wettability or porous structure can fully saturate the electrolyte and accelerate the ionic transport; (3) the polar functional groups (CO, NH, etc.) provide a large number of adsorption sites for Zn2+, which regulates the flux distribution of Zn2+ on the anode surface and induces a uniform Zn deposition. For example, Yu et al. [152] used a similar approach to construct nitrogen-doped 3D hybrid carbon fibers (Sn@NHCF) embedded with Sn nanoparticles (Fig. 13d and e) as a Zn-metal deposition substrate. Sn possesses weak electrocatalytic properties, which prevents the generation of hydrogen bubbles in the battery, and Sn@NHCF carriers can regulate nucleation and dendrimer behaviours mainly by lowering the local current density and facilitating the transfer of ions to make Zn uniformly deposited on the inner and outer surfaces of fibers with low overpotentials. on the inner and outer surfaces of fibers with small overpotentials. At the same time, the hierarchical hollow fibers provide enough space for Zn deposition, which enhances the structural stability while buffering the volume expansion. The electrodeposited Sn@NHCF-Zn anode exhibits excellent electrochemical performance, and the symmetric cell still has a cycle life of more than 100 h under the test condition of 50% discharge depth (Fig. 13f). Beyond that, Zeng et al. [153] developed a 3D hybrid multifunctional body by mixing Cu-NBs with PAN via electrospinning to produce Cu nanobox-embedded nitrogen-doped carbon fibers (Cu-NBs@NCFs) (Fig. 13g and h), which can achieve dendrite-free deposition of zinc anode and improve the Coulombic efficiency and cycling life of zinc anode. The 3D hollow carbon skeleton not only reduces the local current density and mitigates the volume expansion, but the hollow interior can provide space for the initiating Zn deposition. In addition, the Zn-friendly Cu and the in situ formed Cu-Zn alloy can serve as homogeneous nucleation sites to minimise the Zn nucleation overpotential, which further guides the homogeneous and dense Zn deposition. The results showed that 1000 cycles could be stably cycled at a current density of 5 mA cm−2 (Fig. 13i). 4.2.2 Functional interlayer In batteries, chemical reactions such as in-situ formation of solid electrolyte interfaces (SEI), ion transport, deposition and corrosion occur at the electrode/electrolyte interface. The interface on the zinc anode plays a crucial role relative to the thermodynamic stability of the zinc anode and the kinetic processes that ultimately affect the electrochemical performance of the zinc anode. Therefore, by forming an interfacial layer, not only can the deposition of zinc be inhibited, but also the surface of the zinc anode can be protected from direct contact with the electrolyte, thus reducing the occurrence of corrosion side reactions. Polymer composite fibers are usually flexible, ionically conductive and electrically insulating, which facilitates the transfer of Zn2+ between interfacial layers and the uniform deposition of Zn2+. Therefore, surface modification of the anode with microporous polymer nanofiber membranes produced by electrospinning or adding an intermediate layer between the separator and the zinc anode is considered a promising strategy and more conducive to achieving the long-term stability of wearable FZIBs [154]. It was shown that Kim's group [155] investigated PAN nanofiber frameworks with microporous features to effectively mitigate Zn dendrite formation. ESNFs containing polar nitrile groups were prepared by electrospinning and used on an anodic Cu collector (Fig. 14 a), where the interlayer provided conductive channels for Zn2+ and facilitated uniform deposition, thus mitigating the formation of dendrites. Symmetric cells comprising such electrodes (Zn@PAN-Cu) showed more than 270 stable cycles without short-circuiting and showed improved cycling performance by enabling reversible Zn plating/stripping. Meanwhile, polybenzimidazole (PBI) nanofibers, which are rich in nitrogen-containing functional groups, can promote the uniform deposition of zinc (Fig. 14b). In addition to this, Kim's group [156] also produced an electrospun ferroelectric poly(vinylidene fluoride-co-trifluoroethylene) copolymer (P(VDF-TrFE)) nanofiber layer by using electrospinning to introduce a copolymer on a Cu substrate, which was used as an artificial solid-electrolyte interface to act as a current collector. Its unique molecular arrangement structure effectively suppresses the local current density on the Cu surface, achieves uniform Zn deposition, enhances the Coulombic efficiency, and inhibits the formation of dendrites by preventing the electrode from direct contact with the aqueous solution. In the full cell test with MnO2 as the positive electrode, a stable cycling performance of 200 cycles at a current density of 0.5 A g−1 was demonstrated. At the same time, Zhao et al. [157] prepared PBI-Cu backbones using PBI and DMAC as raw materials by electrospinning. In addition, porous PBI nanofibers with polar functional groups uniformly covered the surface of copper foils and did not require adhesives. The highly polar PBI surface containing amine groups can be used as an active site for Zn2+ deposition to improve the electrochemical capacity of the cell (Fig. 14e). The nucleation overpotential of PBI-Cu was lower than that of bare Cu at a current density of 1.0 mA cm−2. More importantly, the cell with a Zn@PBI-Cu anode had a long cycling capability and high capacity retention at 1.0 A g−1 (Fig. 14f). ESNFs membranes are mostly with porous structure, which can improve the electrochemical properties of ZIBs by introducing some fillers while promoting ion transfer and better adapting to the spatial variations during Zn2+ plating/stripping process. Liu [158] et al. prepared a hybrid interface (Zn@TPZA) consisting of a thermoplastic polyurethane (TPU) fiber matrix and zinc alginate (ZA) filler, which acts as a physical barrier between the anode and the electrolyte to mitigate the occurrence of zinc dendrites and corrosion. The Zn@TPZA-coated zinc anodes retained their original shapes even after 30 days of immersion in 2 M ZnSO4 electrolyte. No by-products were detected compared to bare Zn, confirming the excellent corrosion resistance of the hybrid intercalation (Fig. 14c and d). Numerous studies have shown that porous conductive carbon networks prepared by electrospinning polymer nanofibers have high electrical conductivity, remarkable specific surface area and unique anisotropic structure [159,160]. These features can lead to a uniform charge distribution and reduce the nucleation overpotential and diffusion resistance of Zn2+, thus inhibiting dendrite growth and improving cycling stability, which has a promising application in anode interlayers. Liang et al. [161] devised a unique interfacial strategy to modulate the interfacial electrodeposition kinetics and inhibit the formation of dendrites by covering the Zn metal anode surface with an N-O co-doped CNFs interlayer. The results show that the CNFs interlayer has strong Znophilicity, which can effectively trap Zn2+ and induce uniform deposition of Zn on the interfacial layer. Remarkably, the assembled cell can be stably operated at high current density (5 mA cm−2) with a low overpotential of 59.5 mV for 1200 h (Fig. 14g). Besides, Yang et al. [162] successfully prepared flexible coatings (Cu@CNFs) with porous conductive carbon networks (Fig. 14h) by using electrospinning and heat treatment to construct stable zinc anodes. The coating can improve the stability of zinc anode by uniformly distributing the charge and regulating the Zn2+ flux. In addition, the Cu nanoparticles in this coating were Znophilic, which inhibited the dendrite growth of Zn while promoting the uniform deposition of Zn (Fig. 14i). The results showed that the Cu@CNFs-Zn anode had a lower nucleation overpotential (58.3 mV, 5.0 mA cm−2), higher Coulombic efficiency and cycling stability compared to the bare Zn and CNFs-Zn anodes (Fig. 14j), which was attributed to the large surface area of the CNFs and the Zn affinity of the Cu@CNFs coating. Remarkably, the Cu@CNFs-Zn anode was able to provide over 2200 h of stable cycling at 1.0 mA cm−2 with a capacity of 1.0 mA h cm−2.This work provides an effective strategy for the subsequent production of FZIBs. At the same time, in order to effectively solve the problems of water-related side reactions and zinc dendrites in ZIBs. In this regard, our group has innovatively proposed a “backbone-filled” zinc electrode modification layer based on ESNFs membranes to improve the stability of zinc electrodes in battery operation. The combination of hydrophobicity [163] (from the electrospinning PCL membrane as the “backbone”) and cationic selectivity (from Nafion as the filler) can effectively solve the above problems in ZIBs. At the same time, the sulfonic acid groups enriched in Nafion as a filler are crucial to facilitate the transport of zinc ions, which is conducive to the formation of a smooth zinc deposition layer. As the hydrophobicity and mechanical stability of this modified coating play a key role in protecting the electrodes, it effectively improves the cycling stability and service life of symmetric cells and half-cells, and has a wide range of application prospects [164]. The electrochemical properties of electrospinning anode materials in ZIBs are shown in Table 6 . In summary, functional substrates and functional interlayers made by electrospinning technology can be beneficial in solving zinc anode dendrite and corrosion problems due to their high structural stability and sustainability of raw materials. In addition, strategies such as heteroatom doping and adjustment of microstructure can be employed to increase the active sites and expand the contact area between the electrode and the electrolyte, which is conducive to efficient and stable deposition and stripping of zinc, thus improving the cycling stability and rate capability of FZIBs. However, previous studies have completely ignored the issue of substrate channel size. Larger channels would seriously reduce the energy density of the battery, while smaller channels would hinder the immersion of the electrolyte. Therefore, it is important to optimise the channel size of 3D substrates. In addition to this, in the face of future applications of these zinc anodes, several problems and challenges still need to be addressed. (1) The behavior of the electrodeposition and zinc anode mechanisms in the nearly neutral electrolyte at the atomic or molecular levels are partially unclear. (2) Practical materials and techniques must be systematically investigated to improve zinc anode commercialization. (3) Further improvement is required for the zinc anode performance at a great depth of discharge and in the corresponding full batteries. 4.3 Electrospinning separators and polymer electrolytes 4.3.1 Electrospinning separators Among the key components of FZIBs, the separator is a crucial component with the following two roles: (1) separating the two electrodes and preventing physical contact between the zinc anode and the cathode, which may lead to a short circuit of the battery if they come into contact with each other; and (2) as the separator is a channel for the transport of ions through the electrolyte, it is required to have a certain degree of ion screening and facilitation of the transport. Currently, most ZIBs use highly hydrophilic glass fiber separators (GFs). However, due to the unsatisfactory structural and mechanical properties of GF, it is easy to produce Zn dendrites during the ion transport process, leading to short circuit, and thus is not suitable for FZIBs. In order to solve the above problems, domestic and international researchers and scholars have carried out corresponding studies on the separator to improve their physical or electrochemical properties continuously. By changing the base material of the separator, they can achieve stronger performance advantages in battery applications or better suitability in certain systems by virtue of their own properties [165,166]. And studies have shown that electrospinning technology can produce nanofibrous membranes with high porosity and high surface area, as well as micron to nano-sized fiber diameters with higher porosity and electrolyte permeability, which is conducive to electrolyte penetration. Slow down the production of zinc dendrites while avoiding corrosion and decomposition [167]. More importantly, this separator has good flexibility, which is very convenient for the production of FZIBs. Various polymer precursor-based electrospun separators have been investigated in which polar groups act as coordinating sites for cation movement, greatly increasing the contact area between the reactants and the electrolyte [50]. PAN has high thermal stability mechanical strength [168] and has been reported to be effective in inhibiting the formation of zinc dendrites [169]. Zong et al. [170] developed a PAN nanofiber separator for ZIBs using electrospinning technology. The N atoms on the surface of the separator uniformly distribute the ionic flux, thus promoting cation transfer through strong N–Zn bonds. As a result, the electric field is uniformly distributed around the anode, which guides the nucleation, growth and deposition of Zn2+. Zinc symmetric batteries with PAN separators have long-term cycling stability and dendrite free deposition orientation due to the presence of this functional group. Although PAN has good electrochemical properties, the mechanical properties of pure polymer films prepared by the electrospinning method are generally poor, limiting their application in flexible devices. Compared with pure polymer separators, composite polymer separators prepared by mixing different types of substances through the electrospinning method effectively improve the mechanical strength while promoting the uniform deposition of Zn2+. Saisangtham et al. [168] obtained a functionalized ZIBs separator with high mechanical strength from PAN, bio-based diisocyanate (PBDI), ethylene glycol (EG) and DMF. The bio-based polyurethane (TPU) component was made on the basis of a PAN separator. The blending of PAN with highly flexible thermoplastic TPU improves its mechanical properties. The separator has a tensile strength of up to 44.16 MPa, an ionic conductivity of up to 3.11 mS cm−1, and an electrolyte uptake of up to 1971%. In addition, it shows no significant dimensional change even at 150 °C and has a significant ability to physically inhibit the growth of zinc dendrites, resulting in a longer cycle life of the ZIBs. Polyetherimide (PEI) has high tensile strength and dimensional stability. In order to provide better mechanical properties of the separators, Lee et al. [25] synthesised a unique electrostatically spun nanofiber mat-reinforced selective composite (ERC) membrane by immersing poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA) into electrospinning PEI nanofiber mats as a flexible framework. ERC membranes (Fig. 15 a) can be wound along plastic rods (¼ 5.0 mm in diameter) and have no mechanical breakage even after almost folding (Fig. 15b), which is suitable for the application of FZIBs. Experiments have shown that the secondary discharge capacity of the ERC membrane is very large, which not only improves the cycling capacity retention of ZIBs, but also opens up a new avenue for the development of film-driven ZIBs. MOFs materials, as mentioned in previous cathode materials, have many desirable advantages, such as well-defined channels, high porosity, adjustable chemistry, large specific surface area, and controllable channel size. If the brittle MOFs material is combined with an electrospun flexible polymer substrate as a separator, the ion flux can be effectively controlled and the flexibility of the separator can be enhanced. Liu et al. [171] successfully produced MOFs-functionalized electrostatically spun PAN nanofibrous separators through a precise surface grafting strategy. The Zn2+ transport process could be effectively facilitated by placing amino (MOF-N) and sulfonic acid groups (MOF-NS) on the transport channel surface. The synthesised MOF-NS exhibits excellent electrochemical properties due to the strong ion-dipole interactions effectively promoting the dissociation of zinc salts and the desolvation process of hydrated Zn2+. In addition, the flux of Zn2+ can be regulated by adding functional materials such as MXene. Likitaporn [172] prepared PAN/TPU/Ti3C2T x MXene composite membranes by using electrospinning (Fig. 15c and e). Ti3C2T2 MXene was embedded in the fibers to form a spindle-like structure. The composite membranes showed good charge/discharge stability in Zn/Zn symmetric batteries (Fig. 15d). In addition, the developed separators had high flexibility and no change in size and structure after heat treatment, which provided ideas for subsequent studies of FZIBs. The research of ESNFs in FZIBs separators is shown in Table 7 . 4.3.2 Polymer electrolytes As an important component of ZIBs, the electrolyte plays a crucial role in the electrochemical performance of ZIBs. Aqueous electrolytes inevitably suffer from water decomposition reactions, water evaporation, and electrolyte leakage due to the presence of a large amount of free water. Compared with aqueous electrolyte, polymer electrolyte can not only effectively inhibit the occurrence of hydrogen precipitation and corrosion and the growth of dendrites, but also improve the stability and Coulombic efficiency of the battery due to its lower active water content and high elastic modulus property. Furthermore, as a substitute for “electrolyte + separator”, polymer electrolyte can effectively prevent electrolyte leakage while simplifying the manufacturing process and reducing costs, showing great potential for development in the field of electrochemical energy storage and wearable flexible smart materials [173,174].
