Based on their structure and composition, polymer electrolytes can be classified into two main categories: solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) and gel polymer electrolytes (GPEs) [175]. In order to obtain better electrochemical performance, efforts have been made to optimise the composition and structure of polymer electrolytes. Controlled incorporation of multiple components into the electrolyte has resulted in improved electrochemical kinetics and mechanical properties of batteries compared to single-component materials [176]. Electrospinning technology, a popular process for the preparation of porous membranes with fiber structure, allows the construction of fibrous membranes with different compositions. By introducing the desired different compositions, it provides an effective way to design high-performance flexible electrolytes. For example, Hu et al. [177] achieved a two-component functionally composite mono-ionic solid polymer electrolyte in a monolayer structure using a multi-nozzle electrospinning technique. This electrolyte has a stable 3D interpenetrating network structure, which maximises the contact area between the mono-ionic lithium salt and polyethylene oxide (PEO) after hot-pressing treatment. This structure inhibits the separation of the two components while reducing the crystallinity of PEO, which is conducive to improving the ionic conduction rate and enabling the battery to exhibit good multiplicity performance and cycling stability. However, since flexible LIBs are subject to safety and cost constraints, Li et al. [16] investigated a safer and more reliable wearable solid-state FZIBs (Fig. 15f and g), which mainly consisted of a novel gelatin and PAM-based layered polymer electrolyte (HPE) and α-MnO2 CNTs cathode. Due to the careful design of the electrolyte and electrodes, the flexible solid-state ZIBs exhibited high surface energy density and power density (6.18 mW h cm−2 and 148.2 mW cm−2, respectively), high specific capacity (306 mA h g−1), and excellent cycling stability (97% capacity retention after 1000 cycles at 2772 mA g−1) (Fig. 15h). It shows that ZIBs have great potential for practical wearable applications and provide a new platform for wearable flexible energy storage technology. PVDF is by far the better overall polymer monomer, and because of its good flexibility, good chemical resistance and superior thermal porosity, researchers often blend it with one or two polymers to obtain superior GPEs with good mechanical and electrochemical properties [178,179]. For example, Liu et al. [180] used the electrospinning technique to produce PVDF/TPU/PAN-based GPEs with different ratios and high ionic conductivity (6.91 × 10−3 S cm−1) and excellent mechanical properties, and the lithium battery composed of these GPEs had a first discharge capacity of 167.52 mA h g−1, with very little decrease in capacity after 50 cycles. This battery has a high discharge capacity retention rate under current constant voltage conditions. Composite polymer electrolytes can effectively improve the ionic conductivity and mechanical properties of batteries, a finding that has been demonstrated in LIBs. Therefore, in order to improve the overall performance of ZIBs, Likitaporn et al. [181] investigated the preparation of a highly porous polymer electrolyte membrane containing zinc salts with better performance from polyurethane (PU)/PAN (Fig. 15k). For the polymer electrolyte, the use of ionic salts facilitated the Zn2+ transfer mechanism and the addition of different Zn salts enabled the sample to exhibit good flexibility (Fig. 15l). In particular, the high Zn(OTf)2 samples showed a gradually bundled structure with improved contact angle, water absorption and thermal resistance properties. Namely, the ionic conductivity of the 15 wt% Zn(OTf)2 sample was 10 times that of the pure PU/PAN film. Because PU has good flexibility and the polyurethane functional groups have better binding ability with Zn2+, it can provide an effective idea for the subsequent production of FZIBs. In addition to polymer electrolytes, gel electrolytes offer impressive advantages in FZIBs. Not only can they effectively avoid the inherent challenges of aqueous electrolytes, but due to the flexibility of their materials, they can mitigate the dissolution of active substances while withstanding the volume expansion and dendrite growth of the electrode materials, and more importantly, facilitate the bending and folding of FZIBs. However, gel electrolytes in the conventional sense only improve the rate of ion transport and do not optimise the electrochemical performance of the battery. In addition to this, there are problems with physical cross-linking (poor thermal stability) and chemical cross-linking (poor flexibility and elasticity). Therefore, in order to design and develop gel electrolytes with high ionic conductivity, good dimensional stability and long cycle life to better meet the required properties of FZIBs, our group fabricated a composite gel electrolyte (PTP) by injecting TPU, poly (mesitylene benzamide) (PMIA) nanofiber separator skeleton into polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) gel. Due to its robust and ultrathin appearance, inherent ion channels and functional groups capable of immobilising water molecules, it can effectively enhance the Zn2+ transport rate and address the problems of zinc anode dendrites and corrosion. The batteries produced by this strategy showed good electrochemical performance and cycling stability, providing a new idea for the modification of nanofiber-reinforced gel electrolytes [182]. In summary, the polymer gel electrolyte is the key component of FZIBs, which is both separator and electrolyte. With relatively excellent flexibility properties, it can basically meet the needs of FZIBs, improve the multiplication performance of FZIBs, and form good interfacial contact with electrodes. Although the safety and flexibility of the devices have been improved to some extent, there are still multiple challenges that limit their practical applications. For example, (1) Narrow operating temperature range: when the electrolyte is at the limiting temperature, the electrolyte will undergo irreversible chemical reactions (e.g., oxidative decomposition at high temperatures) or physical changes (e.g., solidification in low-temperature environments leading to a sudden drop in conductivity) leading to rapid failure of the battery's performance or even leading to safety accidents. (2) Low voltage window: that is to say, the voltage range it can withstand in practical applications is small, limiting its application in high-voltage equipment. (3) Low ionic conductivity: affects the charging and discharging efficiency and performance of the battery. Therefore, in order to solve these problems, on the one hand, by preparing double mesh gels with highly porous or layered structures is the most feasible way to make the gels have excellent mechanical properties. At the same time, this structure can increase the electrolyte content and promote the migration of Zn2+, thus improving the ionic conductivity. On the other hand, the components of the gel electrolyte should be flexible. Selecting different polymer matrices to couple different zinc salts and modifying the charged groups by cross-linking to influence the migration of Zn2+ is an effective method to improve the ionic conductivity. In addition, by introducing specific functional groups it may be possible to give the gel electrolyte the ability to respond positively to the external environment. Moreover, the introduction of gel electrolytes with solutions having high decomposition potentials is a practical way to expand the operating voltage window. 4.4 All-in-one flexible batteries Currently, the booming markets for smart electronics and smart electric vehicles have led to a widespread need for wearable energy storage devices that are lightweight, flexible, and all-in-one, making them a new trend in the evolution of energy storage devices [183]. Also, the overall performance of all-in-one FZIBs is closely related to the cell configuration. In order to realise FZIBs for flexible electronics, the designed structured devices should have high space utilisation, low contact resistance, excellent deformation robustness and simple device fabrication. Generally, according to the shape of the device configuration, the assembled FZIBs can be classified into 1D fiber-optic type, 2D planar type and 3D sandwich type [184]. In recent years, 1D yarn FZIBs have attracted much attention due to their energy storage capacity and wearability, and have been widely used in flexible wearable electronics such as smart garments, physical detection patches, and electronic skins. In addition, this FZIBs has the unique advantages of being highly flexible, lightweight, and structurally versatile, which can improve the volume specific capacity and flexibility. It can be easily woven with fabrics for large-scale, low-cost production [185]. Chen et al. [186] used a simple weaving technique to integrate the fibrous cathode and anode into the textile, respectively, to assemble an all-in-one yarn FZIBs (Fig. 16 a), which provides an easy way to construct wearable FZIBs. The prepared composite fibre cathode contains reduced graphene oxide (rGO) with high electrical conductivity, which can solve the problems of structural collapse and agglomeration, and at the same time improve the electron transport efficiency of the nanocomposite. As a result, these FZIBs have good discharge capacity and cycling stability (70% retention after 2000 cycles). Besides, Li et al. [160] prepared PAN-coated carbon yarns (CP yarns) from carbon fibre yarns by electrospinning, and deposited polypyrrole nanoparticles on carbon fibre yarns using in situ polymerization to obtain highly conductive and flexible CPP yarns. Finally, zinc was deposited on the CPP yarn by electrodeposition to obtain the CPP@Zn yarn electrode. The results show that the specific capacitance of the electrode remains 86.13% after 500 times of bending. The yarn electrode has excellent electrochemical stability and flexibility, and has a broad application prospect in wearable smart textiles. 2D FZIBs usually have a film-like or paper-like appearance from the surface, with the cathode and the anode on the same substrate and with a certain spacing, a flexible gel electrolyte coated on the surface of the two electrodes, and finally encapsulated with encapsulation material. Generally, they can be applied to energy storage systems for flat electronic devices such as foldable mobile phone screens, digital cameras, and laptop computers [187,188]. Steingart et al. [189] demonstrated FZIBs through a coplanar configuration with flexible silver fabric as substrate and embedded MnO2 and Zn particles as cathode and anode, and polyacrylic acid-based gel as electrolyte and separator, which was sealed in an acrylic elastomeric bag (Fig. 16b). The silver-plated nylon wires are highly flexible and conductive, making the FZIBs highly stretchable. The FZIBs remain highly conductive and have the same capacity when repeatedly stretched by 100 per cent, and the LEDs remain illuminated when stretched at different angles (Fig. 16c). 3D sandwich structures are widely used in various batteries due to the advantages of simple process and low manufacturing cost. In order to fabricate wearable all-in-one FZIBs, the flexible cathode and anode are located on both sides of the gel electrolyte, and due to the strong viscosity of the gel electrolyte, it is possible to combine the electrolyte with the electrode through bonding, thus forming an all-in-one structure. This unique one-piece structure prevents relative displacement or separation between neighbouring components and ensures continuous and effective ion transfer capability inside even if the cell surface deforms, resulting in a device with excellent structural design and stable electrochemical performance [190]. Flexible all-in-one ZIBs are now well established and show potential in wearable and stretchable electronics. For example, Zhang et al. [183] all-in-one rGO/PANI cathode, cellulose nanofibre separator and exfoliated graphene (EG)/Zn anode by total freeze casting to form all-in-one FZIBs. The results show that the all-in-one FZIBs have excellent flexibility and electrochemical stability under different bending states. In addition, Akhmetova et al. [191] prepared “one-piece” flexible LIBs by loading the active materials with PVDF-HFP-based precursor solution and electrospinning three solutions of positive electrode, separator, and electrolyte on top of each other sequentially using electrospinning technique, and finally immersing the membrane (Fig. 16d) in a gel electrolyte. The electrochemical performance of the nanofibers can be improved by adding appropriate amounts of CNTs to both the cathode and anode of the nanofibers. The electrochemical performance of the battery composed of these films remained stable after 40 cycles of bending (Fig. 16e). This work provides an opportunity to develop a new generation of transparent all-in-one FZIBs. In summary, wearable all-in-one FZIBs have attracted much attention for their large capacity, rich storage, and strong security [192]. Meanwhile, in order to increase the application areas and versatility of all-in-one FZIBs, Yao et al. [190] have produced FZIBs with an editable, stretchable, and ultrathin all-in-one structure by using a process that combines blade coating and rolling assembly, which can avoid relative displacement between neighbouring components and ensure a certain degree of ion transport capability. In addition, the sheet-like structure can be customised and edited into desired shapes and structures, further expanding its application areas. What's more, it has been found that using the excellent self-supporting flexible membrane structure of electrospinning-based nanofibers provides another effective way to construct flexible all-in-one batteries [193]. Shao et al. designed a novel all-in-one structured “paper-like” ZIBs by electrospinning PAN nanofilms from PAN as a raw material as a separator, and using in situ deposition of anode (Zn nanosheets) and cathode MnO2 nanosheets (Fig. 16f), which avoids the relative sliding and separation of the integrated layers. Separation, ensuring the formation of monomers in different bending states. The synthesised all-in-one FZIBs have an ultra-thin thickness along with a specific capacity of 353.8 mA h g−1 at 0.1 mA cm−2 and excellent cycling stability (98.7% retention after 500 cycles at 1 A cm−2). The flexible zinc-ion batteries retained 98% of their capacity after 200 cycles when bent at an angle of 180° (Fig. 16g) [28]. 5 Conclusions and outlook With the development of ZIBs, FZIBs are now considered a sustainable option for powering portable electronic devices. Recent studies have shown that the preparation of electrospun FZIBs provides an effective means and exhibits unique advantages:(1) By modulating the precursor solution, electrospinning can fabricate common nanoscale anode and cathode materials; (2) By adjusting the electrospinning process and post-processing, the controllable morphology, structure, and composition of electrospun materials can be well realized; (3) The 1D nanostructures prepared by electrospinning can be interconnected into a 3D network, which improves electrical conductivity and structural stability by promoting electron/ion transfer. And the 3D network generally behaves as a flexible fibrous membrane, which facilitates the production of self-supported binder-free flexible electrodes. Therefore, electrospinning technology provides an effective way to realize FZIBs. In this review, firstly, after we introduce the basic principles of electrospinning, we discuss that composite nanofiber materials with a variety of structures and compositions can be produced for various components of batteries (cathode, anode, separator, and polymer electrolyte) by precise tuning of the parameters of the electrospinning process. The basic principles of FZIBs and some of their problems are then outlined and the application of ESNFs in FZIBs is summarized. Although electrospinning has many advantages in producing high-performance, safe and reliable FZIBs and all of them have been widely researched, there are still some problems and challenges that need to be further explored and upgraded with innovative technologies in the future development, as follows. 5.1 Optimization of electrospinning technology The setting of electrospinning parameters is closely related to the microstructure (pore size, heteroatom doping, etc.) of ESNFs. By combining electrospinning technology and finishing process, ESNFs with different structures (porous, hollow) can be prepared to improve the electrochemical performance of FZIBs. Currently, strategies such as heteroatom doping and defect engineering have been realized to increase the active sites, expand the contact area between the electrode and electrolyte, and promote the transfer of Zn2+, thus improving the interfacial stability and rate capability of FZIBs. In subsequent studies, to further enhance its flexibility, fiber-based batteries can be directly produced by compounding with technologies such as microfluidics. Alternatively, all-in-one FZIBs can be directly produced through precise design by one-step or multi-step on-line direct production. Batch production is an important indicator for practical applications. Improvements based on electrospinning techniques, e.g. multi-needle electrospinning, airflow-assisted electrospinning, and other highly efficient nanofiber preparation techniques have been developed to further achieve the yield. In addition, various techniques can be employed to improve spinnerets (e.g., multi-needle, needleless) and traps (e.g., rollers, fixed filaments) for large-scale and highly efficient preparation of nanofibers. At present, the preparation of FZIBs containing all components (cathode, anode, separator, etc.) by electrospinning is still in its infancy, and the flexibility of ESNFs has not yet reached commercialisation. Therefore, it is necessary to continue developing new highly flexible conductive materials for FZIBs. However, while satisfying the high flexibility of FZIBs, attention should also be paid to their electrochemical properties in order to achieve a balance between the two. 5.2 In-depth understanding of the mechanism of FZIBs The electrochemical charging and discharging of FZIBs is a multi-stage process that is influenced by a variety of factors. An in-depth understanding of this process is necessary for the design and optimisation of battery structures. However, the basic understanding of mass transfer and electrochemical processes in flexible batteries under external forces is still lacking. We need to pay great attention to this problem. Only in this way can some strategies be used to improve the energy density of FZIBs and solve the problems of zinc anode dendrite, cathode structure collapse, and cell deconstruction and delamination. In order to facilitate the rapid development of wearable FZIBs, a comprehensive understanding of the mechanical and electrochemical behaviour offlexible batteries is important. In addition to basic experimental data, advanced characterization techniques and model analysis are effective methods to gain insight into the actual battery situation, which can effectively explain and analyse some of the battery properties during bending. Therefore, with the accumulating and expanding knowledge of electrospinning, its application in FZIBs will be affirmed soon. 5.3 Optimization of battery design The overall performance of FZIBs is inextricably linked to their individual components, so it is particularly important to optimise the design of the battery. Currently, most FZIBs still use aluminium-plastic materials for their outer packaging, which will form folds on the packaging or electrodes after continuous folding or bending. The presence of folds not only increases the resistance of the electrodes and hinders the effective transfer between materials, but also reduces the utilisation of active materials. Therefore, in order to meet the wearability of future electronic devices, it is necessary to develop flexible battery packaging materials that are lightweight, thin in thickness, stable in performance, and have excellent barrier properties, so as to protect the battery materials, electrolytes, and electrochemical reactions from the external environment. In addition, flexible batteries still contain liquid electrolyte, which reduces the performance of the batteries while there are problems such as liquid leakage, electrode corrosion and material dissolution. Therefore, further research on electrospun electrolytes is needed to improve their application in flexible batteries. Self-supported non-bonded electrodes have attracted a lot of attention due to their ease of use and flexibility in cell assembly. Although ESNFs have been used as bondless electrodes in FZIBs, it is difficult to obtain an optimal porous structure while maintaining the mechanical strength of the electrode for large-scale applications. For example, some metal oxide fibers are usually too weak to be used as self-supporting cathodes. To solve this problem, we can enhance the mechanical stability of self-supported electrodes by physical modifications such as stretching and heat treatment, but care must be taken to avoid overstretching to prevent electrode fracture. 5.4 Battery evaluation under morepractical conditions Currently, many of the reported FZIBs are recycled at low current densities and limited area capacity, which is a far cry from practical applications. Large‐scale evaluation at the pouch level is still deficient. Future evaluation of FZIBs is encouraged to be conducted under more realistic operating conditions (larger current densities, wider operating temperature, appropriate electrolyte, etc.). Currently, there is no established measurement method that can accurately characterize flexibility. Therefore, there is a need to establish evaluation criteria that are consistent with standardized flexibility, such as the effect of electrode bending radius or numbers of bends on electrical properties and electrochemical behaviour. 5.5 Realization of practical applications For technical and other reasons, there are no commercially available battery plants for FZIBs. Suitable electrolytes and compatible electrodes are key issues for the sustainable development of flexible batteries. Although flexible zinc-based batteries have performed well in the laboratory, many problems remain in practical applications, partly due to the substandard performance of hydrogel electrolytes in harsh environments, which affects battery quality and lifetime. For example, when the temperature is lower than 0 °C, it restricts the ionic migration of FZIBs, leading to a decrease in ionic conductivity and affecting the flexibility and tensile properties of the electrolyte. When the temperature is higher than 60 °C, it accelerates the anodic side reaction, leading to poor contact between the electrode and the electrolyte, which seriously affects the mechanical and electrochemical properties of FZIBs. Therefore, practical applications can be achieved by designing weakly solvated electrolytes to extend their operating temperature range. In addition, the actual capacity and mechanical properties of FZIBs are not ideal. To solve these problems, the capacity of FZIBs can be enlarged by increasing the amount of loaded active substances to make them more widely practical. Although the above challenges still exist, the general application of FZIBs with low cost and high energy/power density in flexible electronic devices (e.g., roll-up displays, smart electronic devices and wearables) is highly anticipated in the near future. coredata.dc:description: Flexible wearable batteries are widely used in smartwatches, foldable phones, and fitness trackers due to their thinness and small size. Zinc-based batteries have the advantages of low cost, high safety, and eco-friendliness, which are considered to be the best alternative to flexible lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). Therefore, wearable flexible zinc-ion batteries (FZIBs) have attracted considerable interest as a promising energy storage device. Electrospun nanofibers (ESNFs) have great potential for application in wearable FZIBs due to their low density, high porosity, large specific surface area, and flexibility. Moreover, electrospinning technology can achieve the versatility of nanofibers through structural design and incorporation of other multifunctional materials. This paper reviews a wide range of applications of electrospinning in FZIBs, mainly in terms of cathode, anode, separator, polymer electrolyte, and all-in-one flexible batteries. Firstly, the electrospinning device, principles, and influencing parameters are briefly described, showing its positive impact on FZIBs. Subsequently, the energy storage principles and electrode configurations of FZIBs are described, and some of the common problems of the batteries are illustrated, including zinc anode dendrite growth, corrosion, cathode structure collapse, and poor electrical conductivity. This is followed by a comprehensive overview of research progress on the individual components of FZIBs (cathode, anode, separator, and polymer electrolyte) from the perspective of electrostatically spun fiber materials and an in-depth study of all-in-one flexible batteries. Finally, the challenges and future development of FZIBs are individually concluded and look forward. We hope that this work will provide new ideas and avenues for the development of advanced energy technologies and smart wearable systems.
